content.intro:
The Danes say they are happy to be alive, and this affirmation of vitality is especially felt in their capital, Copenhagen.

The emblem of the city is the little mermaid from the Hans Christian Andersen fairy-tale, who, from her rock, seems to observe the Copenhagen harbour with an air of melancholy. Yet Copenhagen hardly engenders melancholy. Denmark's capital offers visitors a double facet: that of a city proud of its architectural heritage and that of a metropolis with a warm and minimalist design that is resolutely turned towards the future.

Whatever the period chosen for strolling in Copenhagen, you cannot help being seduced by its gentleness and friendliness, which the Danes call hygge, an expression that means creating a warm atmosphere and enjoying the present moment with good people.

To counter the cold to which the Scandinavian regions are prone, the city is draped in multiple colours. The most famous example is the picturesque Nyhavn harbour district, where Hans Christian Andersen lived for 18 years and where the colourful facades are reflected on the waters of the canal. But you can admire dollhouse architecture everywhere in Copenhagen, with elegant brick buildings covered in pretty pastel colours.

The city hosted the 2009 United Nations summit on global warming, and a respectful relationship with the environment is very apparent, as bicycles are king. You will have no trouble finding a rental store, so like any good self-respecting Copenhagener, take the opportunity to ride a bike. It will be your best ally for discovering Copenhagen's secrets, as you ride through its many cobbled streets.

The numerous bars and restaurants reflect the cosmopolitan richness of the city, a legacy of long ago when Copenhagen was only a small port of merchants, founded by the Vikings. After your tour by bike, relax around a good beer brewed on site and enjoy a smorrebrod, a slice of buttered bread accompanied with fresh products that will delight your taste buds with their simplicity and quality.

Welcome to the capital of Denmark, which has made pampering a real lifestyle!

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Copenhagen

seoData.seoTitle: Travel Guide Copenhagen  - Plan your trip to Copenhagen with Air France Travel Guide
seoData.seoDescription: Stay in Copenhagen: what to visit to Copenhagen, where to stay, which restaurant to go? All information to prepare your holidays to Copenhagen with Air France.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Copenhagen

content.title: Zahida, maternal cuisine from the Pendjab

introduction.small: Far from Nordic standards, explore other horizons at Zahida, a Pakistani restaurant where welcoming patrons is an art in itself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zahida, maternal cuisine from the Pendjab

paragraphs.text:
For Shane and Bobby Affridi, Zahida is first and foremost their own mother. She who prepared for them, on a daily basis, all kinds of traditional recipes from the Pendjab region of Pakistan, where she is from. She used to carefully choose ingredients one by one at the market. And each day, it would seem she created a new dish. Today, the two brothers define the restaurant as a tribute to “Mamī“, and by extension to all mothers across the globe. There, they re-enact all habits and gestures they watched during childhood in order to prepare the best gastronomy you will find from South Asia. Highlighting ethical, local and quality products, Shane and Bobby Affridi conceive authentic recipes, with meat or vegetarian options. For starters, Pakistani samosas will take you to a faraway place with their potato, green pea, mint and tamarind stuffing. Keep on with a Makhni Chana, a chickpea-based traditional dish with tomatoes, butter and creamy sauce served with rice and a garlic naan. Alternately, choose the masala lamb shanks like no other. End the meal on a light touch with a pistachio ice cream. You will definitely feel like a guest at a family meal…

Zahida
Rømersgade 20
1362 København K

+45 52 24 03 66

https://www.zahida.dk

Menu: around 230 DKK

content.title: A ski resort in the city

introduction.small: Creating a mountain on the roof of a waste treatment centre. Such is the crazy concept of CopenHill, where you can ski, trek and climb.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A ski resort in the city

paragraphs.text:
Denmark is known for being a pretty flat land. So, imagine the surprise when an urban mountain sprung out in the heart of Copenhagen. Rest assured, there is no magic involved: this installation named CopenHill is actually the rooftop of… a power station, which produces electricity and hot water by burning recycled materials. This incredibly bold project, turning the roof of a waste treatment centre into a playful walkway, now gives locals the opportunity to go down ski slopes, use climbing walls, hiking trails and various other public spaces.

All year long, enthusiastic riders enjoy the second highest Danish skiing area. In the summer, families wander amid picturesque landscapes, with unobstructed views over the artificial islands and wind turbines, whereas budding archers cordially compete in harmless battles, while committed climbers face nothing less than the tallest wall of Northern Europe.

CopenHill
Vindmøllevej 6
2300 København S

+45 51 94 19 20

https://www.copenhill.dk/en

content.title: Amass, hymn to sustainable gastronomy

introduction.small: With its no waste, local and organic stance, Amass nonetheless upholds a gastronomic standard. This makes it one of the most popular restaurants amond ecofriendly food lovers in Copenhagen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Amass, hymn to sustainable gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In an old industrial warehouse overlooking the ancient docks of Copenhagen, Amass stands out with its ecological drive. Run by chef Matt Orlando (who has had some experience at Noma, the Danish starred restaurant), it offers ethical cuisine. Everything is recycled, oriented towards a no waste philosophy: ingredients are sourced from small local producers, meats are exclusively provided by ethical farms, herbs and vegetables are grown in the organic garden that faces the dining room… As for the recipes, they include surprising products that are no less delicious: whipped kale butter, yoghurt whey, nasturtium leaf oil… All those efforts have actually been rewarded with the Michelin “sustainable gastronomy” label.

According to this logic, the single menu changes regularly, depending on available products, the seasons, and even the weather. Dishes you may be able to try include roasted spaghetti squash, served with mussel emulsion, horseradish and salted pumpkin seed, a three-way turbot (ceviche in buckwheat milk, beechwood smoked or cooked in horseradish stew), as well as glazed duck in smoked almonds and grilled elderflower. Modern Nordic flavours and ecological thinking do mix at Amass, making it a must of Danish gastronomy!

Amass
Refshalevej 153
1432 København K

+45 43 58 43 30

https://amassrestaurant.com/home/

Single menu: 700 DKK

content.title: Traditional Nordic recipes at Barr

introduction.small: Only two steps away from the Inderhavnsbroen bridge in the centre of Copenhagen, Barr has become a must in the gastronomic landscape with typically North European dishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Traditional Nordic recipes at Barr

paragraphs.text:
Located by one of Copenhagen's numerous wharves, Barr reveals a very relaxed and welcoming atmosphere. The restaurant is entirely dressed up in wood, from the walls to the counter, the floors and the furniture. Nordic and rustic recipes are given pride of place, but culinary traditions from the whole North Sea, Scandinavia, Benelux and even the British Islands also find their way onto the menu.
In the kitchen, the chef sublimates the famous "marmite", a yeast-extract-based spread, by integrating it into classic Danish dishes. Order some smoked mackerel, crab and Belgian waffles or the famous fish frikadelle served with truffle, corn and white currant in season. To celebrate traditions even further, beer and food pairings are being offered. A delightful immersion into Nordic gastronomy.

Barr
Strandgade 93
1401 København K

+45 32 96 32 93

https://restaurantbarr.com/en/home/

Menu: around 365 DKK

content.title: Hotel Sanders, five-star Danish stay

introduction.small: In a 19th-century house of the Copenhagen's city centre, Hotel Sanders is a boutique hotel dedicated to Scandinavian art of living.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Sanders, five-star Danish stay

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of Copenhagen, surrounded by the Royal Danish Theatre, the Opera and the Amalienborg Palace, Hotel Sanders takes up a large 19th-century townhouse. Inside, decoration subtly harks back to the stage world, especially through the various photographs that adorn the walls. And with good reason, for hotel owner Alexander Kølpin was a national figure of the art scene, and awarded world best ballet dancer in 1993.
Alexander loves to bring out Danish cultural heritage with slight touches. The common parts of his boutique hotel unveil minimalist and cosy decoration that mixes marble and wood, enlivened with a few expressionist paintings. As for the rooms, they showcase a hybrid style, between a retro bistro and contemporary design. If some of them are connected (an ideal solution for travelling families), they most importantly bring hygge - the Scandinavian art of living - to another level, in which you will definitely feel just like home.

Hotel Sanders
Tordenskjoldsgade 15
1055 København K

+45 46 40 00 40

https://hotelsanders.com/

Rooms: from 2,700 DKK

content.title: Illum Original Coffee, a coffee shop and a view!

introduction.small: Gain height and discover Copenhagen from another perspective: head to Illum Original Coffee's terrace to try a delicious coffee made in Denmark!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Illum Original Coffee, a coffee shop and a view!

paragraphs.text:
Before discovering the incredible views of Copenhagen, head through the Illum department store, a Scandinavian design temple dedicated to shopping and the pleasures of fine dining. After slowing down in front of its luxury shops, the scent of roasted coffee beans will lead you up to the top floor. There, you will find the largest rooftop in the Danish capital, with six restaurants and the teak terrace of the famous Illum Original Coffee.
Inside, the clinking of percolators sets the pace for agile baristas who, behind the counter, prepare the best coffee in the city. Arabica and Robusta are served in ristretto and Americano form, while the surface of a cappuccino reveals the features of a beautiful drawing in the foam of the milk. Get comfortably seated among the soft cushions of colourful benches dressing this cosy and bright space. The panorama is so beautiful and coffee so delicious that you will not see time pass.

Illum Original Coffee
Østergade 52
1001 København K

+45 33 14 40 02

https://illum.dk/en/food/illum-rooftop

Coffee: from 35 DKK

content.title: Kødbyen, when Manhattan comes to the Danish capital

introduction.small: Where butchers once ran their businesses now lies a myriad of trendy places, where you can hop from one to the next, day and night, to discover underground Copenhagen...

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kødbyen, when Manhattan comes to the Danish capital

paragraphs.text:
In the Vesterbro district, divided into three distinct zones according to the dominant white, grey or brown-coloured buildings, the Kødbyen area was still reserved for butchers selling livestock and cold cuts in the 17th century.

While its name and history are inspired by the most fashionable neighbourhood of New York (it is also known as the Meatpacking district in the English-speaking world), the atmosphere in Kødbyen is quite similar as well. In 2005, after a decision from the city council to avoid the area becoming a ghost town, a plethora of galleries, cafes, bars, clubs and other arty addresses set up shop.

There you will find trendy Danish and international nightlife each evening, dine in fabulous restaurants and sip cocktails created by experienced mixologists. During the summer, mingle with hipsters who gather to shop at the local organic produce market. A friendly and trendy atmosphere that makes it a hotspot of the Danish avant-garde.

Kødbyen
1711 København V

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/neighbourhoods/guide-meatpacking-district

content.title: Danish Brunch at Mad & Kaffe

introduction.small: Open from 8:30 a.m. onwards, Mad & Kaffe welcomes early risers and epicureans alike, coming to enjoy the best brunch in town. A spot to revel in the calm morning vibe…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Danish Brunch at Mad & Kaffe

paragraphs.text:
Mad & Kaffe (or food and coffee) will meet your most demanding breakfast expectations. In a bright setting where the large bay windows open onto a beautiful spacious room, you will be offered an à la carte service. Indeed, here everyone chooses their menu according to their tastes, preferences and hunger level. Whether you go for the 3, 5 or 7-course menu is up to you. A list of ingredients is available for each dish: that includes vegetables, proteins (animal or vegetable), dairy products and pastries.

Once your order is placed, a series of dishes, each more delicious than the next, will be brought to you. Homemade cream cheese melts on warm rye bread while cinnamon heightens the savoury applesauce. Mushrooms are added to the egg brouillade accompanied by a few slices of the Scandinavian speciality, the ever-present smoked salmon. An exquisite way to start the day, fully satisfied, before heading off to conquer the city!

Mad & Kaffe Vesterbro
Sønder Blvd. 68
1720 København V

+45 31 35 08 80

https://madogkaffe.dk/restaurants/brunch-vesterbro-eng/

Menu: from 94 DKK

content.title: A moment in nature at the Copenhagen Botanical Garden

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, stroll through the Copenhagen Botanical Garden, a favourite spot for nature lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A moment in nature at the Copenhagen Botanical Garden

paragraphs.text:
North of Copenhagen is the cosmopolitan area of Nørrebro, which probably best reflects the changes in the Danish capital. A former working-class area, it has kept a certain authenticity.

Now, immigrants, hipsters, yuppies, and families live alongside designer shops, restaurants, kebab kiosks, and flea markets, where you can buy designer furniture at a reasonable price, Nørrebro being generally one of the most accessible areas of Copenhagen.

When you are done shopping, discover the serenity of the Assistens Cemetery. Unlike Latin cemeteries, Nordic cemeteries have nothing austere or sad about them. This one is no exception. In this environment, which is more of a public garden, it is not uncommon to see couples kissing, people picnicking, or a family playing among the simple graves. Hans Christian Andersen, the storyteller, and Kierkegaard, the philosopher, are both buried there. In many respects, the Assistens Cemetery is the image of Nørrebro: a place where life flows peacefully.

Assistens Cemetery (Assistens Kirkegård)
Kapelvej 4
2200 København N

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/planning/norrebro-gdk957596

content.title: Relæ: the minimalism of the New Danish Cuisine

introduction.small: A Michelin star and a restaurant with an elegant yet informal atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Relæ: the minimalism of the New Danish Cuisine

paragraphs.text:
If you do not have the patience to wait six months for a table at Noma, the Relæ is the best alternative, and most importantly, much cheaper. Located in the cosmopolitan district of Nørrebro, the address has a Michelin star, and was ranked 45th recently in the prestigious San Pellegrino list of the 50 best restaurants in the world.

Its former chef, Christian Puglisi, an emblematic figure of the New Danish Cuisine, is also head of Manfred and a former line chef at NOMA. He paved the way for new Canadian chef Jonathan Tam. The influence of that four-time winner of world's best restaurant is felt. Again, no tablecloth and it is up to you to set the table with cutlery from the drawer. There is only one menu: you simply choose either four or seven dishes. The gastronomic particularity of the dishes is due to the freshness and quality of the local products, with a colourful yet minimalistic visual presentation.

Relæ
Jægerborggade 41
2200 Copenhagen N

+45 36 96 66 09

www.restaurant-relae.dk/en

Menu: from 484 DKK

content.title: Manfreds, a restaurant featuring mostly organic products

introduction.small: Try the quasi-vegetarian restaurant that reinvents Danish cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manfreds, a restaurant featuring mostly organic products

paragraphs.text:
An iconic address in Nørrebro, the trendy, multicutural district of Copenhagen, Manfreds is both a gourmet restaurant and wine bar. It was also the first organic wine bar in Copenhagen. This same product/quality concern is reflected in the menu, because since 2013, the restaurant has been awarded ‘organic certification', which alone can ensure that what ends up on your plate and in your glass is 90-100% organic.

The cuisine of chef Christian Puglisi, whose impressive CV lists him as a former line chef at Noma and the current starred chef at Relæ, relies on a unique menu of seven locavore dishes. By bringing forgotten vegetables to the fore and working with what the chef finds every day at the market, Manfreds boldly reinvents Danish cuisine in an informal setting.

Manfreds
Jægerborggade 40
2 200 Copenhagen

+45 36 96 65 93

manfreds.dk/en

Menu: from 260 DKK

content.title: The Little Mermaid: an iconic figure in the Danish capital

introduction.small: Watching over Copenhagen since 1913, she has become its emblem.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Little Mermaid: an iconic figure in the Danish capital

paragraphs.text:
Perched on a rock near Churchill Park for more than a century, the Little Mermaid has become the symbol of Copenhagen, and by extension, that of Denmark, much like the Eiffel Tower is the symbol of Paris. In tribute to its original spiritual father, writer and storyteller, Hans Christian Andersen, the small bronze statue was erected in 1913 by Edvard Eriksen and attracts over a million tourists annually.

You may be surprised by its lack of a fish tail, but remember that according to Andersen, once on land, the tail is replaced by legs. The statue may also surprise by its small size (1.25 m) but do not underestimate it. Not only has it inspired a large well-known animation studio, but it has also faced numerous acts of vandalism since the 1960s, including beheadings and the amputation of an arm. To get here from the city centre, walk along the seafront past Amalienborg Castle to Langelinie Dock.

The Little Mermaid (Den Lille Havfrue)
Langelinie
2100 København Ø

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/kobenhavn/planlaeg-din-tur/den-lille-havfrue-gdk586951

content.title: Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek Museum displays 10,000 works

introduction.small: Carl Jacobsen's extensive collection of antiques and Impressionist works is a must-see in Copenhagen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek Museum displays 10,000 works

paragraphs.text:
If you had to visit only one museum in Copenhagen, the Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek Museum would be it. Located within walking distance of Tivoli Gardens, it was inaugurated in 1897 by the patron of the arts, Carl Jacobsen, son of the founder of the Carlsberg breweries empire.

A good place to start is the luminous and captivating subtropical winter garden where, seated next to a palm tree, you can enjoy an organic snack, perhaps the chocolate cake, reputed to be the best in all of Copenhagen. Fortified, you may then start in on the different museum collections, all of which are of the highest quality. You will find sculptures by Danish artists (Herman Wilhelm Bissen, Peder Severin Krøyer, Astrid Noack…), of course, but also ancient pieces (including the recreation of a Roman temple) and a sublime collection of works by French sculptors of the Impressionist and Post-Impressionist period. Discover masterpieces by Degas (his famous Danseuse), Cézanne, Renoir and on through to Manet, Van Gogh and Gauguin… especially Gauguin! An entire room is dedicated to him (he married a Dane), tracing his artistic journey through his various trips, from Brittany to Tahiti.

Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek Museum
Dantes Plads 7
1556 København V

+45 33 41 81 41

https://www.glyptoteket.com/

content.title: Noma: four times named the ‘best restaurant in the world'

introduction.small: Noma promises a unique gastronomic adventure you will not forget any time soon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Noma: four times named the ‘best restaurant in the world'

paragraphs.text:
If you happen to plan lunch or dinner at Noma, book way in advance, possibly even before leaving home...

Since 2010, this starred restaurant has been listed four times as the world's best restaurant by Restaurant magazine (in 2010, 2011, 2012, and 2014 respectively). Chef René Redzepi is extremely bold in reinventing Nordic gastronomy, sometimes to the point of shocking diners. Noma is in fact an acronym for Nordic gastronomy: 'Nordisk Mad'.

So be warned that your culinary experience here will be unique, away from stilted or established standards. You will not find a tablecloth on Noma tables and the servers, adorable modern-day Vikings with tattooed arms, bring you the 20 dishes that make up one of the three tasting menus with a certain nonchalance: “Vegetables” (vegetarian and vegan) from June 25th to September 21st, “Game and forest” from October 15th to December 21st, and “Seafood” from January 7th to May 30th. The number of dishes might sound scary, but the well-thought-out servings do not make you feel the heaviness characteristic of many more traditional meals.

Noma
Refshalevej 96
1432 København K

+45 32 96 32 97

https://noma.dk/

Menu: from 2,500 DKK

content.title: Nyhavn, the typical Scandinavian charm of the harbour

introduction.small: Strolling around the Nyhavn canal is a fine way to admire a palette of colours in a warm and friendly setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nyhavn, the typical Scandinavian charm of the harbour

paragraphs.text:
Imagine a canal where a great number of old wooden boats are moored, bordered on each side by a series of buildings reminiscent of doll houses, whose bright colours are reflected in good weather in the waters. In winter, snow and ice replace the water, giving the place an almost magical Christmas atmosphere. This is the Nyhavn quarter for you, one of the most picturesque tourist areas of the Danish capital.

Built in the 17th century by King Frederik V, the canal connecting the Baltic Sea to the old town was intended to make it possible for boats to reach Kongens Nytorv (Royal Square). It suffered a bad reputation for a long time because thieves, drunken sailors, and prostitutes congregated there. Today the shady taverns have become restaurants and cosy bars that are crowded as soon as a ray of sunshine appears. In winter, the atmosphere remains warm: the terraces are heated and restaurants distribute blankets.

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/planning/nyhavn-gdk474735

content.title: Nimb: a timeless, cosy place

introduction.small: Experience the magic of Tivoli Gardens while staying at Nimb, the palace of the Arabian Nights, in sumptuous Danish comfort.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nimb: a timeless, cosy place

paragraphs.text:
A few steps from the Tivoli Gardens is Nimb's facade, which, after nightfall, is lit by lamps along its entire length that reflect beautifully in the waters of the fountain. Suddenly you are transported into a tale from the Arabian Nights. The staff, who are helpful and attentive, will also make you feel like a maharajah.

But the comparison stops there. All 38 rooms are elegantly appointed with antique furniture in grey and chocolate colours, overlooking Tivoli Gardens to which you have free access. In this luxurious establishment, kids are not forgotten: babysitting services, special menus at breakfast, adapted minibar and connected bedrooms are ideal for vacationing families. Finally, there is no doubt the six gastronomic restaurants will accommodate your appetite, not to mention the bar, where you can sip your seasonal cocktail under the antique crystal chandeliers of the ballroom.

Nimb
Bernstorffsgade 5
1577 København V

+45 88 70 00 00

https://www.nimb.dk/en/hotel

Rooms: from 2,800 DKK

content.title: SKT. PETRI Hotel: a spacious, luminous hotel

introduction.small: Enjoy the best that Danish design can offer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SKT. PETRI Hotel: a spacious, luminous hotel

paragraphs.text:
Ideally located in the heart of Copenhagen's Latin Quarter, with direct access from the airport by metro, the SKT. PETRI hotel is striking with its imposing red facade that looks straight out of a 1970's sci-fi movie. Whatever your choice of room among the 268 available, you will enjoy the cosy atmosphere. The rooms, with their blond wooden floors, their comfortable grey armchairs, and warm colour palette for which we can thank Danish artist Per Arnoldi, offer a welcoming and pleasant stay in this lively neighbourhood. If you are staying in the Petri Suite you will enjoy a generous terrace with a beautiful view over Copenhagen's historical past and rich medieval heritage.

For the complete SKT. PETRI experience, remember to book a table at the PETRI restaurant, whose modern decor is complemented by nice lighting and high ceilings. The menu, like the cosmopolitan city of Copenhagen, features elegant Danish and International cuisine.

SKT. PETRI Hotel
Krystalgade 22
1172 København K

+45 33 45 91 00

https://www.sktpetri.com

Rooms: from 1,575 DKK

content.title: The Nørrebro: an authentic, multicultural district

introduction.small: In the Nørrebro district, the vibrant thrum of life can be felt everywhere, even in the Assistens Cemetery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Nørrebro: an authentic, multicultural district

paragraphs.text:
North of Copenhagen is the cosmopolitan area of Nørrebro, which probably best reflects the changes in the Danish capital. A former working-class area, it has kept a certain authenticity.

Now, immigrants, hipsters, yuppies, and families live alongside designer shops, restaurants, kebab kiosks, and flea markets, where you can buy designer furniture at a reasonable price, Nørrebro being generally one of the most accessible areas of Copenhagen.

When you are done shopping, discover the serenity of the Assistens Cemetery. Unlike Latin cemeteries, Nordic cemeteries have nothing austere or sad about them. This one is no exception. In this environment, which is more of a public garden, it is not uncommon to see couples kissing, people picnicking, or a family playing among the simple graves. Hans Christian Andersen, the storyteller, and Kierkegaard, the philosopher, are both buried there. In many respects, the Assistens Cemetery is the image of Nørrebro: a place where life flows peacefully.

Assistens Cemetery (Assistens Kirkegård)
Kapelvej 4
2200 København N

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/planning/norrebro-gdk957596

content.title: Rundetårn: Copenhagen's Tower of Babel

introduction.small: Climb the spiral ramp and admire one of the best views of Copenhagen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rundetårn: Copenhagen's Tower of Babel

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking Copenhagen from a height of 34 m, Rundetårn (literally 'Round Tower') offers a breath-taking panorama. Built in the early 17th century by order of King Christian V, it was originally intended for students so they could have a place of observation. In order to facilitate the delivery of astronomical equipment, a surprising and unique architectural choice, the first in Denmark, was made to build a spiral ramp 209-m long.

Even today this architectural masterpiece is surprising for its ingenuity and luminosity. Halfway up you can catch your breath in the former university library, which has now become a showroom. You will need your breath to climb the rest of the ramp, but especially if you decide to enter the hollow heart of Rundetårn where a glass floor looks down from a height of 25 m to the floor below.

The view from the summit is a little less frightening perhaps. From the top of the Observatory, the 360° view gives you a great overview of the old Copenhagen and the bridge connecting Denmark and Sweden. Also note that, depending on the month chosen for your visit, you may have the chance to gaze at the stars from the Observatory.

Rundetårn
Købmagergade 52A
1150 København K

+45 33 73 03 73

https://www.rundetaarn.dk/en/front-page/

content.title: Torvehallerne Market: the rendezvous for lovers of quality products

introduction.small: Torvehallerne Market, for lovers of quality products

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Torvehallerne Market: the rendezvous for lovers of quality products

paragraphs.text:
Enter Torvehallerne and there is a whole palette of colours, smells, and sounds that hit you. If the market exists here since 1889, locals have had to wait until 2011 for two permanent and covered food markets to be added and opened to the public, along with a food court.

With its two large modern halls of steel and glass, this is the largest covered market in Copenhagen. 700 sqm of quality products for every budget and for all tastes are available, ranging from sweet and salty to local specialties like smørrebrød or foods from elsewhere, like fish & chips and Italian pastas.

If you are gluten intolerant, head to Vita Boost, a specialised take-away (paninis, muffins, smoothies, etc.), or to the Unplugged Juice, which offers 100% gluten free wraps and cookies.

Once your choice is made among the Torvehallerne stalls, take a seat at a counter and enjoy your food with the knowledge that you have opted for an alternative that is as affordable as it is pleasant.

Torvehallerne Market
Frederiksborggade 21
1360 København K

+45 70 10 60 70

https://torvehallernekbh.dk/

content.title: Tivoli Gardens: a timeless amusement park

introduction.small: The Tivoli Gardens offer hours of amusement and rides, assuring children and adults of a joyful outing.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tivoli Gardens: a timeless amusement park

paragraphs.text:
The Tivoli Gardens are a must for a family stay in Copenhagen and though there are certainly gardens, that is not all that is on offer. As the second oldest amusement park in the world, opened in 1843, it attracts nearly four million visitors each year.

Once inside, the enchantment is total. There is a Ferris Wheel built in 1914, adjacent to a Chinese pagoda and the Moorish facade of Nimb. What emerges from this garden is a quaint charm, close to the world of Jules Verne, always punctuated with laughter and joyous cries, as well as a certain magic. It is not unusual to see a peacock on a path, walking about in total freedom.

Hans Christian Andersen visited here in his time, and it is also in his honour that the 'Flying Suitcases' (Den Flyvende Kuffert) attraction was added to the park. However, you may prefer Norse mythology, in which case the Valhalla Borgen (Fort Valhalla) attraction is for you.

Tivoli Gardens (Københavns Tivoli)
Vesterbrogade 3
1630 København V

+45 33 15 10 01

https://www.tivoli.dk/en/

content.title: Strøget: Copenhagen's shopping street

introduction.small: Strolling the longest pedestrian street in the country is the best way to enjoy its numerous shops.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Strøget: Copenhagen's shopping street

paragraphs.text:
Strøget is the longest pedestrian street in Denmark, and when it opened, was the longest in Europe. It is a necessary stop if you want to window shop. Originally designed to relieve congestion in the Danish capital, the shopping street is for pedestrians and pedestrians only, and in a city where cycling is ubiquitous, this is an important detail.

Stretching over more than a kilometre, it is hard not to find something among the many decoration and fashion shops, from international brands (e.g. Benetton, Zara, Vera Moda), to local labels (e.g. Gina Knitting, a competitor of H&M).

As a family, the Lego shop is well worth the visit. The well-known Danish toy brand opened a shop in 2010 where, advised by a smiling staff, you can admire giant representations of Copenhagen and acquire, thanks to the 'Pick a Brick' wall, any piece individually. An ideal opportunity to revisit childhood.

Strøget
1160 København K

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/planning/stroget-gdk414471

content.title: Granola Café: a must for ‘brunchers'

introduction.small: Discover one of the best brunch places in Copenhagen in a quaint bistro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Granola Café: a must for ‘brunchers'

paragraphs.text:
Located in Frederiksberg, a former working-class district of Copenhagen, the Granola Café is a popular address with locals. The first reason for this success lies in Granola's look, as the place has character reminiscent of the atmosphere of a small Parisian bistro.
The second reason for this success is its varied brunch menus. Perhaps, before heading off to explore the city, you will opt for the big breakfast plate, the Granola's Breakfast Platter, with organic eggs, bacon, avocado and lemon peel, 24-month old Comté and Naturmælk Brie cheeses. With seasonal fruits and berries, wholewheat bread and croissants, the meal is complete!
You might still opt instead for a simple chiagrød, a porridge with chia seeds, almond milk, vanilla, peanut butter, seasonal berries, fresh mint and grilled almonds. Whatever your choice, you are sure to enjoy fresh products, served by a casual staff that is nonetheless effective and fast, despite the crowds.

Granola
Værnedamsvej 5
1819 Frederiksberg C

+45 33 33 00 95

www.granola.dk

Menu: around 155 DKK

content.title: Hotel Alexandra: a tribute to retro design

introduction.small: Sleeping at the Alexandra will take you back to the 1950s.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Alexandra: a tribute to retro design

paragraphs.text:
Fans of Mad Men and vintage design will be right at home in any of the 61 rooms at the Alexandra. Here, the decor is decidedly retro as the owners, connoisseurs of Danish creation of the 1950s and 1960s, have given the rooms real character and a certain elegance.

Design lovers will appreciate the homages made to the great names in Danish creation such as Verner Panton, Finn Juhl, Hans J. Wegner and Arne Jacobsen. The rooms, although quite small (the exception being the 25-square-metre Verner Panton room) are well appointed. Above all, the hotel is ideally located: a nine-minute walk from the station, seven minutes from Tivoli Gardens, and two minutes from the Strøget shopping street.

The always helpful and friendly staff will provide the key to exploring the city, wherever you happen to be, by showing you how to use an app (free) that features all the best addresses in Copenhagen.

Hotel Alexandra
H. C. Andersens Boulevard 8
1553 København V

+45 33 74 44 44

https://www.hotelalexandra.dk/

Rooms: from 896 DKK

content.title: Kompa 9: a café with discreet and authentic charm

introduction.small: A little-known address for tourists, where the coffee is as good as it is at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kompa 9: a café with discreet and authentic charm

paragraphs.text:
After a shopping spree on Strøget, give yourself a break in one of the parallel streets: Kompagnistræde, for example, where you will find Kompa'9.

There is a cosy and almost rustic atmosphere at Kompa'9, perhaps due to the fireplace and the wooden tables, on which candles and bunches of flowers are placed. All these elements invite the customer to take the time to linger, flipping through the choice of magazines on the metal display, and to enjoy a cup of coffee or tea, hot or cold apple juice, or even their renowned hot chocolate, made with Bojesen organic cocoa, chocolate provider for Noma, often awarded the title of “best restaurant in the world” and only five kilometres away.

The atmosphere is quiet, yet conducive to exchanges with the Copenhageners who frequent the place. So you have no reason not to go there, especially since, for Copenhagen, the prices are rather interesting…

Kompa'9
Kompagnistræde 9
1208 København K

+45 33 12 31 25

https://www.facebook.com/Kompa9Cph/

Menu: drinks from 25 DKK

content.title: Andersen Boutique Hotel: a comfy designer hotel

introduction.small: Your comfort is assured as a guest of the Andersen Boutique Hotel, with its colourful rooms and fairy-tale atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Andersen Boutique Hotel: a comfy designer hotel

paragraphs.text:
Just a two-minute walk from the Central Station and its metro in the heart of trendy and vibrant Vesterbro, Andersen Boutique Hotel provides an atmosphere that reflects the warm and welcoming character of the city. In the 69 brightly coloured rooms, the emphasis is on design, with signed bathroom furniture by Philippe Starck and tapestries from the Designer's Guild. The carefully chosen design conveys a magical touch, not least in the choice of the themed rooms, such as 'Emperor', 'Princess' and 'Mermaid'. So which will you choose?

Your day at Andersen Boutique Hotel starts with a rich and varied breakfast buffet, with everything you need to fortify yourself for visiting the city on foot or by bicycle (the hotel can rent one to you). Do not hesitate to ask the smiling and always attentive staff any questions you may have on the city's best addresses. In the late afternoon, take advantage of the hotel's 'wine hour', which is an opportunity to enjoy a good glass of wine in company, and maybe even get to know other travellers.

Andersen Boutique Hotel
Helgolandsgade 12
1653 København V

+45 33 31 43 44

https://andersen-hotel.dk/en/

Rooms: from 1,580 DKK

content.title: Christianshavn: a quiet, affluent neighbourhood, rich in architectural discoveries

introduction.small: Attached to Copenhagen and yet at a remove, the Christianshavn district charms by its tranquillity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Christianshavn: a quiet, affluent neighbourhood, rich in architectural discoveries

paragraphs.text:
Christianshavn or 'Little Amsterdam' is an island east of Copenhagen, where the canals are longer and more winding. The mostly residential are a houses, among other neighbourhoods, the Free City of Christiania, and its tranquillity contrasts with the energy of Copenhagen, on the other side of the canal.

The best way to discover Christianshavn is still by boat. The more athletic and adventurous can opt for cycling or kayaking. During your visit, take time to admire the picturesque coloured facades reflected on water (not unlike Nyvhan) and the imposing Opera House built in 2005. If you still have the energy, the Baroque Church of Our Saviour, with its surprising spiral tower, is worth seeing.

The panorama visible from the summit is reputed to be one of the most beautiful in all Copenhagen, but be warned, there are 400 steps that you must climb including the last 150 outside, which are very exposed to the wind.

Christianshavn
København H

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/christianshavn

content.title: Bertrams Hotel, eco-friendly exotic charm

introduction.small: Exceptional value for money, Bertrams Hotel Guldsmeden will delight eco-conscious travellers who are concerned about consuming differently.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bertrams Hotel, eco-friendly exotic charm

paragraphs.text:
Located in Vesterbro, the new trendy area of Copenhagen, Bertrams Hotel is the most intimate property of the Danish company Guldsmeden. This group, differing from most of its purely Scandinavian-design competitors, seeks to establish a warm, yet more exotic atmosphere in its hotels.

This place is no exception and, in rooms with four-poster beds, the Balinese influence is complemented by Persian rugs. Particular care is taken to respect the environment, whether in the excellent organic breakfast consisting of local products, or in the toiletries made with essential oils.

The charm of Bertrams Hotel is undoubtedly its small courtyard, where you can come and relax whenever you like the friendly staff will offer blankets if needed. For greater quiet, think about booking a room overlooking the courtyard.

Bertrams Hotel
Vesterbrogade 107
1620 København V

+45 70 20 81 07

https://www.bertramshotel.com/

Rooms: from 1,535 DKK

content.title: Christiana: the Utopia of the 1970s

introduction.small: Visit Christiana, and become aware of another way of life.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Christiana: the Utopia of the 1970s

paragraphs.text:
'To live happily, live hidden' is a principle followed to the letter by the Christiana community, which prohibits photos within its walls. Christiana is a city within a city, a refuge of creation and alternative culture.

It is because they felt on the margins of society that the founders had the idea in 1971 to build Christiana, which they established in an abandoned military barracks. Today, the 'free city' enjoys a special status as a ‘social experiment'. Specifically, it operates on a self-management system that applies to politics (approximately 1,000 people vote their own laws), but also to water, electricity, waste, education, and culture... Ditto for the symbols: Christiana has its own flag, its own currency, and its own anthem, 'I kan ikke slå ihjel' (You cannot kill us!).

The third most popular tourist destination, after the Little Mermaid and Tivoli Gardens, Christiana surprises with its anarchic and bohemian atmosphere, so feel free to admire the ubiquitous street art, to contribute to the survival of the city by purchasing handicrafts, and to stroll about in this unusual and very green setting.

Christiana
Prisessegade
1440 København K

https://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/planning/christiania-gdk957761

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Copenhagen
content.introduction: Copenhagen has a temperate oceanic climate. Summers are mild and relatively dry and winters are cold, but without extreme temperatures in either season.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Denmark is the Danish Krone (DKK).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Copenhagen-Kastrup Airport
airports.description:
The Copenhagen-Kastrup Airport is located about eight kilometres (5 miles) south-east of the city centre, on the island of Amager.
  • Three terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2 (Air France departures)
    • Terminal 3 (Air France arrivals)

Getting from the airport to Copenhagen and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the E20.
    • Four parking facilities are available at the airport:
      • Budget (outdoor lots from DKK 105 to 115 per day)
      • Standard (from DKK 50 for 1 hour to DKK 220 for 1 day)
      • Standard+ (DKK 50 for 1 hour, DKK 250 for 1 day)
      • Direct (from DKK 50 for 1 hour to DKK 320 for 1 day)
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall at Terminal 3.
  • By metro
    • Line M2 of the Copenhagen Metro connects Terminal 3 (Lufthavnen station at the north end of the terminal) with the city centre in about 15 minutes. The fare is DKK 38 each way.
  • By bus
    • Bus lines 5A, 35 and 36 connect the airport to the Central Station, run every 10 minutes from 7:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., every 15 minutes from 6 p.m. to 11:30 p.m. and from 4:30 a.m. to 7:00 a.m. and every 20 minutes from 11:30 p.m. to 4:30 a.m. The fare is DKK 38 each way.
  • By train
    • Danske Statsbaner (DSB) operates trains linking the airport with Copenhagen Central Station (København H) in about 12 minutes, leaving from platform 2. The fare is DKK 38 each way.
    • o The SJ company operates express train from the airport to Malmö (about DKK 122), Göteborg (about DKK 480) and Ystad (about DKK 182). Trains leave from platform 1 in terminal 3, a 15-minute walk from terminal 2.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside terminals 2 and 3. Fares to central Copenhagen from DKK 250 to DKK 350.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +45 32 31 32 31
  • Website: https://www.cph.dk/en

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Copenhagen
transportation.description: Copenhagen is an easy city to get around. Its public transport options are all convenient, efficient and very reliable. In addition, Metro and bus fares are integrated: a two-zone ticket (covering all of central Copenhagen) costs DKK 24 and may be used on both Metro lines and all of the buses.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Copenhagen, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Copenhagen Visitor Service
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Vesterbrogade 4A, 1620 København V
  • Telephone: +45 33 25 74 00
  • Website: https://www.visitcopenhagen.com

information.title: Denmark travel guide
information.description:
The official website developed and maintained by VisitDenmark, the Danish tourist office, provides a wealth of information on Copenhagen.

  • Website: https://www.visitdenmark.com/

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Copenhagen counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to Denmark.
For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr/
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no food safety risks in Copenhagen.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Copenhagen.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Danish phrases that will make your stay in Copenhagen a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Goddag
What time is it?: Hvad er klokken?
How much is (...)?: Hvad er prisen på (…) ?
Where can I find (…)?: Hvor kan jeg finde (…)?
Where can I buy (…)?: Hvor kan jeg købe (…)?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Copenhagen
localCalendar.description:
There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Copenhagen each year.
The main ones are listed below.

events.title: April 16: Birthday of Queen Margrethe II (Dronningens fødselsdag) (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: On this day, thousands of flag-waving Danes flock to the square outside the Amalienborg Palace before noon to wish the queen a happy birthday. Following the changing of the guard, the royal family steps out onto the palace balcony to acknowledge the cheers of the crowd. Shortly thereafter, the Danish Royal Military guards parade through the city's streets on horseback, leading the royal couple in an open carriage.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (Arbejdernes kampdag) (national holiday)
events.description: Danes take advantage of this work holiday by gathering in the 56-hectare (138-acre) Fælledparken in Copenhagen to enjoy picnics organized by the various trade unions, an opportunity to relax and have fun with colleagues.

events.title: May 5: Liberation Day (Danmarks befrielse) (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the end of the German occupation during World War II. In 1945, at the announcement of the liberation, many Danes placed lit candles in their windows. In remembrance, many elder people still honour this tradition every year.

events.title: May: Copenhagen Marathon (local event)
events.description: Each year, runners from around the world compete in this popular event, which passes in front of many of the Danish capital's most beautiful landmarks and includes a large section along the waterfront. The course starts and ends in front of the Black Diamond, the extension to the Royal Library, where runners are cheered by throngs of spectators.

events.title: June 5: Constitution Day (Grundlovsdag) (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the constitution signed on this day in 1849, under which the country became a constitutional monarchy, as well as the new constitution adopted on the same day in 1953. Many political meetings and ceremonies are organized, together with cultural events and celebrations, including concerts and other performances.

events.title: June 21-23: Midsummer's Eve (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Although June 21 is officially the summer solstice, Saint John's Eve on June 23 is considered as the actual midsummer eve in Denmark and is celebrated by sharing a feast with family and friends.

events.title: Second Friday in October: Culture Night (Kulturnatten - local event
events.description: For this event, cultural institutions, arts venues, houses of worship and architectural treasures in Copenhagen open their doors to the public from 6 p.m. until midnight for exhibitions and guided tours. A single ticket provides admission to more than 300 museums, libraries, educational establishments and churches in the Danish capital.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Denmark
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be staying in Denmark for less than three months. However, your national identity card or passport must be valid for the duration of your stay.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Copenhagen and Denmark, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Denmark page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs:
https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/denmark/#

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERNMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March
End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Copenhagen as in the rest of Denmark, all restaurant, hotel and taxi bills include a service charge. It is therefore unnecessary (but always appreciated) to leave any additional gratuity. However, if you are especially pleased with the service, it is customary to tip as much as 10% of the bill.
